name: Chicago Parent Program (CPP)
summary: A group-based, evidence-based parenting program designed to promote positive parent–child relationships, reduce behavior problems, and improve parenting confidence, particularly in diverse, urban, and underserved families.
description: The Chicago Parent Program (CPP) is a group-based parenting intervention developed with input from African American and Latino parents to ensure cultural relevance and accessibility. It emphasizes positive parenting strategies such as praise, encouragement, and consistent discipline, while reducing harsh or inconsistent practices. The program is delivered in small groups using video vignettes, group discussion, and home practice assignments. CPP has been shown to improve child behavior, increase parenting confidence, and reduce parenting stress across diverse populations, including low-income families.

off_label_uses: Reducing parenting stress in high-risk populations
contraindications: Parents unable to attend group sessions regularly
Families requiring intensive individual therapy due to safety concerns (e.g., active abuse)
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and well-tolerated. Some parents may experience temporary stress when trying new strategies.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Supported by studies in diverse, low-income, and urban populations showing reductions in child behavior problems and improved parenting practices.

sections.text: CPP works by strengthening positive parenting skills, improving parent–child communication, and encouraging consistent discipline practices. Group sessions include video examples of real parent–child interactions, followed by discussion and role-play. Parents are encouraged to apply skills through weekly home practice, gradually shifting family interaction patterns toward greater consistency, warmth, and reduced conflict.

sections.preparation: Parents are recruited through schools, clinics, or community programs. Orientation introduces the program’s goals and structure.
procedure: Weekly group meetings led by trained facilitators.
View and discuss video vignettes depicting common parenting challenges.
Role-play alternative approaches and reinforce positive strategies.
Assign and review home practice activities.
sections.total_treatment_time: 24 hours of group contact, plus home practice.

sections.treatment_phase: Discussion of video vignettes, skill teaching, group role-play.
sections.post_session: Summarize key skills, assign home practice.
sections.home_practice: Parents implement new strategies and track progress with their children.

immediate: Increased awareness of positive parenting strategies
long_term: Enhanced child academic and social functioning

common: Temporary frustration as parents adjust to new strategies
uncommon: Dropout due to scheduling or group discomfort

absolute: Active abuse or imminent safety concerns
relative: Families needing highly individualized therapy or crisis intervention

ideal_candidates: Parents of toddlers and preschoolers with disruptive behavior
Families from urban, low-income, or minority backgrounds
screening_required: Initial intake to assess family goals
Screen for safety risks and appropriateness of group format

practitioner: Facilitators trained in CPP curriculum (often social workers, psychologists, or parent educators)

studies: Gross D. et al. (2003): Initial development and testing of CPP in African American and Latino families.
Gross D. et al. (2009): RCT showing CPP reduced child behavior problems and improved parenting confidence.
Garvey C. et al. (2014): Long-term follow-up demonstrating sustained benefits.
sections.limitations: Requires group participation, which may limit accessibility for some families; outcomes may vary if home practice is inconsistent.

sections.typical_session_cost: Often delivered at low or no cost through community or school programs
sections.insurance_coverage: Sometimes covered under group therapy or parenting education
sections.cost_effectiveness: Considered cost-effective due to reductions in later behavior problems and school issues.

sections.low-income-families: Designed with input from urban African American and Latino parents, ensuring cultural relevance.
sections.immigrant-families: Adaptable with translation and cultural tailoring.
sections.school-settings: CPP has been implemented effectively in preschool and elementary schools.

items: Group-based peer support is a key component of CPP.
Video vignettes help normalize parenting challenges and encourage discussion.
CPP may be used preventively as well as for families already struggling with child behavior.
